election_record.label: New Hampshire 1806 Governor

candidate.name: Philbrock
candidate.note: Listed in Original Election Returns as Captain Philbrock.

overview.note: The New Hampshire Federalists made no organized effort to elect a Governor and scattered their votes among several candidates.
The Official Results list John Langdon with 15,277 votes.

"The annual meeting for the choice of state, county and other officers, was holden throughut the state on Tuesday last. There is no doubt of the re-election of His Excellency John Langdon.--Indeed no opposition, no systematized exertions have been made to counterbalance the vigilance and adroitness of the democrats.--They have been alert as usual, and, we learn, issued their pamphlets, previous to the meeting, for electioneering purposes. The federalists, voting unbiassedly, dependent on no one for instruction for whom to give their suffrages, have supported several of the best men in the state, as their opinions of the abilities, and integrity of the candidates happened to be. His Excellency the late governor was voted for in some places. The Chief Justice, and Judge Farrar, in others. Though sensible of the improbability of electing their favourite candidate, it affords a pleasing reflection to know that their principles are still unchanged, and that they still prefer a disciple of the Washington School to the man who now holds the helm of government. The foundation of their political principles is not placed on a crumbling basis of sand, but rests on the stable rock of truth; unmoved by the violent and temporary gusts of party. Under these circumstances the time cannot be far distant when our fellow citizens will again embrace their former sentiments which they have been deprived of by the deceptive arts of demogogues. ... As no exertions have been made to counteract the reelection of Mr. Langdon, we expect to hear much pitiful boasting of the great majority of votes he will have in the state. This will be in character." Farmer's Museum (Walpole NH), March 14, and New-hampshire Sentinel (Keene, NH), March 15.

"The votes at the close of the poll were unanimous for that venerable, highly respected and tried friend and patriot of his country, His Excellency John Langdon, Esq. as Governor. This is greater evidence than volumes of newspaper panegyric could possibly give,--that his administration the last year has been unexceptionable and highly approved of, even by those who were once his political enemies. He has convinced multitudes that He, (in the language of our beloved President) views all good federalists as GOOD REPUBLICANS. For in his numerous appointments and promotions the past year, it is very generally known, he has not been influenced in the least by sinister, party, or political views;--but his only enquiry has been, is the candidate an honest, upright character, and friend of his country!--and if the affirmative, HE has never raised an objection. This honorable, generous, noble conduct in a Chief Magistrate, is deserving the eulogy of the ablest pen.--There is no doubt but HE is nearly unanimously re-elected Governor of this State the ensuing year; therefore we think it will be quite unnecessary to continue our weekly list of votes, as on former occasions, when there has been a contest between rival candidates." New-Hampshire Gazette (Portsmouth, NH), March 18.

sub_unit.name: Adams
sub_unit.note: The votes from Adams were rejected.

sub_unit.name: Colebrook
sub_unit.note: The votes from Colebrook were rejected.

sub_unit.name: Percy
sub_unit.note: "No return." Original Election Returns, Percy Town Records.

sub_unit.name: Lyman
sub_unit.note: The votes from Lyman were not included in the Original Election Returns.

sub_unit.name: Kearsage Gore
sub_unit.note: John T. Gilman received 5 votes as John Gilman.

sub_unit.name: Barrington
sub_unit.note: "Not returned in season." Original Election Returns.
